Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They offer small gestures of kindness in daily interactions
Story: Tonight, my stepdad is hosting a family dinner, and everyone expects me to be there. My mom keeps reminding me how important it is to show up, to be part of the family, to make my stepbrother feel welcome. But earlier today, I saw him at school, teasing a new kid in the hallway. I wanted to step in, to say something, but I hesitated. Now, as I get ready for dinner, I feel this knot in my stomach. As a Christian, I know I should show love and kindness, even to those who hurt others. I want to reach out, maybe talk to my stepbrother, or at least not ignore him. But I’m also angry and disappointed, and I don’t want to pretend everything is fine at dinner. My family expects me to be cheerful and present, but my faith tells me to be honest and loving, even when it’s hard. I stand in front of the mirror, torn between keeping the peace at home and following what I believe is right.
